Certainly! Here is a revised version of the grid with more detailed information in the topography/land type and climate/rainfall columns:

| Region | Suitable crops | Suitable livestock | Topography / land type | Climate / rainfall |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Branco River | Rice, beans, cassava | Cattle | Flat, fertile soil | Tropical, rainy season from January to May, average annual rainfall of around 2,500 mm |
| Pacaraima Mountains | - | Goats, sheep, dairy cattle | Hilly, cooler climate | Tropical, rainy season from January to May, average annual rainfall of around 2,000 mm |
| Serra do Tepequém | Rice, beans, cassava | Cattle | Flat, fertile soil | Tropical, rainy season from January to May, average annual rainfall of around 2,500 mm |

Overall, the Branco River region is suitable for a wide range of crops and cattle farming due to its flat, fertile soil and tropical climate with a rainy season from January to May and an average annual rainfall of around 2,500 mm. The Pacaraima Mountains region is particularly suitable for livestock farming, particularly goats, sheep, and dairy cattle, due to its hilly terrain and cooler climate, as well as its tropical climate with a rainy season from January to May and an average annual rainfall of around 2,000 mm. The Serra do Tepequém region is suitable for cattle farming and growing crops such as rice, beans, and cassava due to its flat, fertile soil and tropical climate with a rainy season from January to May and an average annual rainfall of around 2,500 mm.
